* By the end of the 3-year period of the contract it is expected that approximately 75% of assisted passage <span class="highlight">migrants</span> will travel by air from Britain and northern Europe. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* Already the movement of assisted passage <span class="highlight">migrants</span> by air has grown to half the total assisted passage programme. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* I emphasise that, contrary to the impression given by the right honourable member for Melbourne, it is not valid to say that 50% of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> elect to travel by sea. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* Because of commitments to sea berths it has been necessary in the past to have this proportion of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> travel by sea. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* The right honourable member for Melbourne also mentioned the advantage to <span class="highlight">migrants</span> from Europe travelling by sea in that there is provision for training in the English language. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* As 85% to 90% of the people carried under this contract are from Britain there is little weight in the argument that by curtailing sea travel we are denying <span class="highlight">migrants</span> the opportunity to learn English. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* There is no evidence at all available to me or to my Department which suggests that <span class="highlight">migrants</span> settle down more readily if they travel by sea, or that there is a greater returnee rate amongst <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who travel by air. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* I do not see that the voluntary organisations or other people nominating <span class="highlight">migrants</span> will be disadvantaged because of air travel. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* It should be remembered that 50%, and sometimes more than 50%, of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> now travel from the United Kingdom by air. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* The large air movement of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> over the past 10 years has demonstrated that the 88 lb of luggage a person provided for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> coming by air has been sufficient to cover the belongings that they wished to bring with them. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* I am confident, as is my Department, that the new arrangements for the carriage of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> will prove to be effective in future years. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* Many of those recently settled, such as <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, are still in the process of buying their homes and the closure of the gold mining will simply mean that a substantial number of these people will be obliged to pack up and leave Kalgoorlie without a penny to bless themselves with. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700415_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-27-0)

* 1 preface my question to the Minister for Social Services by reminding him that yesterday the honourable member for Perth asked the Minister for Immigration whether he was aware of the concern and resentment of elderly <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who found that, in spite of naturalisation, they are denied the age pension because they have not been in Australia for 10 years and he referred to their complaints of being treated as second class citizens. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-4-0)

* Further, is it not a fact that the Australian Labor Party also required <span class="highlight">migrants</span> to become Australian citizens before being eligible to receive age pensions and is it not a fact that it was this LiberalCountry Party Government which removed this bar to the receipt of pensions by <span class="highlight">migrants</span>? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-4-0)

* This Government and its predecessors have done more in this field to help <span class="highlight">migrants</span> than any other government has done. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-4-0)

* I will be happy to provide the House and the honourable member with a detailed account of what the Government has done in this field, but I suggest to the House that we have gone as far as it is possible to go in helping <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who meet some misfortune when they arrive in Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-4-0)

* It is true, of course, that pensions payable in Australia are vastly greater than the pensions available in the countries from which many of these <span class="highlight">migrants</span> come. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-4-0)

* As the honourable member for Wide Bay says, a lot of British <span class="highlight">migrants</span> as well. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#debate-29)

* We arc told that, of some 185,000 <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who will come to Australia in 1970, approximately one-third will settle in the West. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#debate-29)

* I contend it is unnecessary, just as it is unnecessary to require <span class="highlight">migrants</span> to meet a 3-year residential qualification. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#debate-29)

* In the meantime are Maltese <span class="highlight">migrants</span> with British status restricted to a residential qualifying period in the same way as are aliens. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-31-18)

* Is there a residency qualification, notwithstanding naturalisation, of 10 years for eligibility for an age pension and 5 years for eligibility for an invalid pension for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> from most countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-31-22)

* If so, do some <span class="highlight">migrants</span> therefore receive the invalid pension until they reach the age of 65 years (for males) or 60 years (for females) and then lose all pension benefits until they have been in this country for 10 years and become eligible for an age pension. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700416_reps_27_hor66/#subdebate-31-22)

* I ask the Minister for Immigration whether his attention has been drawn to a recent article in a South Australian newspaper quoting  Mr Giordano,  publisher of a monthly bulletin, as saying that more should be done in the field of housing for <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* Will he comment also on the progress of the new flat programme for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and indicate when this programme will be applied to South Australia? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* J recall seeing the article to which the honourable gentleman refers and, as 1 interpret my recollection of that article,  Mr Giordano  was suggesting that the Commonwealth should provide flats which could be sold to <span class="highlight">migrants</span> at low rates of interest. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* The question of permanent accommodation for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> does not fall within my sphere of responsibility but I want to observe two factors. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* States are the principal suppliers, of relatively low cost housing for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement the Commonwealth has made available substantial sums of money to the States to finance these programmes but the Commonwealth has no control over their implementation. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* In the second place, since the inception of the migration programme it has generally been agreed that <span class="highlight">migrants</span> should not be placed in a position of advantage or preferment in connection with housing or other facilities by comparison with native born members of the Australian community. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* However this does not preclude measures being taken to offset the disadvantages at which resettlement places <span class="highlight">migrants</span> vis-a-vis the Australian community. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* In answer to the latter part of the honourable member's question as I recall it, I inform him that our responsibility as a Commonwealth lies in the provision of initial transitory accommodation for Commonwealth nominated <span class="highlight">migrants</span> which takes 2 forms, flats and hostels. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* What consideration has been extended to the proposal that a reciprocal agreement should be negotiated between Australia and Malta which would have the effect of extending to <span class="highlight">migrants</span> from Malta of British nationality the same social service benefits which accrue to <span class="highlight">migrants</span> from Britain and New Zealand. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700421_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-28-3)

* What is the total number of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> resident in Australia who are eligible for naturalisation but who as yet have not applied for naturalisation? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-5-0)

* Why do eligible <span class="highlight">migrants</span> not apply for citizenship? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-5-0)

* I recall that, when I last checked the matter to which the honourable member refers, I ascertained that as at 30th June 1969 there were some 208,000 <span class="highlight">migrants</span> over the age of 16 years and residentially qualified for Australian citizenship who had not made application. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-5-0)

* The fact that a number of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> do not make application for Australian citizenship results, I believe, from a fusion of factors which would include indecision at to longterm permanent residence in Australia; the fact that they may be waiting for other members of the family to become eligible before themselves making application; unawareness of the importance of citizenship; or being aware, the fact that they have not come to the point of making application or would prefer to become further established in the Australian community before playing a complete and meaningful part. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-5-0)

* It has always been the policy of the Commonwealth Government that <span class="highlight">migrants</span> should become Australian citizens, not so much for the material benefits which this would confer upon them but rather because citizenship, once conferred, would enable them to play their full part as Australian citizens in the affairs of the community and to have the opportunity of total identification with the people of Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-5-0)

* by leave -  Mr Speaker,  one of the major new immigration initiatives to be taken by the Government in the course of this Parliament is in the area of migrant education - an area vital to the effective integration of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> into the Australian community. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-0)

* The Government has approved details of a comprehensive programme of migrant education which will strengthen existing provisions and give effect to the policy announced by the Prime Minister  (Mr Gorton)  on 8th October 1969 of Commonwealth financial support for new, improved and expanded facilities for the instruction of child and adult <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in the English language. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-0)

* The Government recognises that the ability of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> to communicate is fundamental to their successful integration. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-0)

* There are short and long term social and human benefits for the migrant and for the community in encouraging and providing the means for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> to learn English. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-0)

* New areas of need have become evident, and whilst there have been practical reasons in the past to concentrate on speaking and understanding the English language, the comprehensive programme now proposed will provide for more emphasis in the future to be placed on reading and writing English, on meeting the individual needs of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and on their citizenship education. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-0)

* The comprehensive programme will provide for: The expansion of existing facilities for the instruction of adult <span class="highlight">migrants</span>; the provision of intensive full time English language courses for those who must know English so that they can be employed in the occupations and professions for which they have been trained and are qualified; and classes for migrant school children with English language difficulties. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-0)

* I believe that a lack of knowledge of the language of the country sponsoring a great migration programme is the greatest barrier to the integration of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and their social and economic success. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* I am reminded particularly of the problem associated with the education of the children of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* The first, most obvious, and most severe problem area for many <span class="highlight">migrants</span> is language. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* Whilst we deal with the problems of children and teachers and questions relating to the social and economic integration of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, at this stage there appears to be a much more lively interest being taken by the Government and organisations in the education of adult <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* He said that a survey by the Department of Immigration indicated that about one-third of foreign born <span class="highlight">migrants</span> cannot speak English and that departmental English classes assist only a small proportion of them. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* He went on to say that women and <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in the age group 30 to 39 years are largely missing from numbers attending English classes. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* One aspect of the migration programme that appears to come under criticism at this stage is that, whilst thousands of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> are being brought to the country, the States are not being given a commensurate amount of money to provide education, housing and other factors associated with a great migration programme. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* If this programme is fulfilled in the way that the Minister has outlined today and comes to fruition as he has said, it undoubtedly will be a forward step in providing for the education of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and their integration into the community. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* At this stage I see no reason why it should be opposed - we may be able to improve it - and I join with the Minister in expressing the hope that it will allow the thousands of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who today suffer from not having a thorough understanding of the English language to integrate socially and economically and in every way take full advantage of the opportunities given to them in this country under the migration programme. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* There are great numbers of young <span class="highlight">migrants</span> from the Villawood migrant hostel going to that school. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700423_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-16-7)

* 7m for departmental other services include $1.5m for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, $4.4m for embarkation and passage costs for <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, $2.2m for the Australian Broadcasting Commission, $].6m for war and service pensions and allowances, $].4m for other repatriation benefits, $5m for the Ship Building Division of the Department of Shipping and Transport, $1.3m for grants under the Aged Persons Homes Act and $l.lm for remission of taxes and fines under special circumstances. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700505_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-21-0)

* What action has been taken to rectify the position discussed by Professor W. F. Connell in  his  back-ground paper 'Education for Adult <span class="highlight">Migrants</span>' for this year's Citizenship Convention. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700505_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-33-33)

* The comprehensive programme outlined in that statement with respect to adult <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and' intensive courses will provide remedies in a number of the areas to which Professor Connell referred in his paper 'Education for Adult <span class="highlight">Migrants</span>'. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700505_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-33-33)

* There are also medical and hospital benefits for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> during their first 2 months in Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700506_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* Surely they cannot all be tories in the extreme who are coming as <span class="highlight">migrants</span> from the United Kingdom to Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700506_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-18-0)

* On Sunday night I had the pleasure and privilege of meeting about 40 medical practitioners, 5 of whom were <span class="highlight">migrants</span> from England. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700507_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-25-0)

* I represent one of the industrial areas of Australia where there are large numbers of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who wisely come to be represented in the seat of Wills. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700507_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-25-0)

* In countries where foot and mouth disease is known to be prevalent or endemic and from which regular shipping services operate it is usual for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who are defined as 'rural' types to be given visas which restricts them to travel by sea. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700507_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-26-14)

* The reason for favouring sea travel for 'rural' <span class="highlight">migrants</span> is because the longer travelling time reduces the amount of any chance virus contamination that may be present. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700507_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-26-14)

* In similar countries from which it is not possible for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> to travel by sea, air movement is permitted but under conditions where a thorough pre-flight examination of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> clothing and baggage is conducted, with disinfection of footwear as necessary, under the supervision of an Australian medical officer. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700507_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-26-14)

* 1 might acid that my Department does everything possible to assist <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in relation to the provision of suitable accommodation for them, and our efforts to assist the Thomas family will continue. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700513_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-11-0)

* I ask: In view of the expected decrease in housing approvals, has the Minister modified his stated target of 175,000 immigrants for the year 1970? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700514_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-3-0)

* Has the Minister issued instructions to his departmental officers to warn prospective <span class="highlight">migrants</span> that the Government has a conscious policy of reducing the housing available to them? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700514_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-3-0)

* We realise the importance of housing to <span class="highlight">migrants</span> but the honourable gentleman will well appreciate the overall exigencies which must guide Government policy. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700514_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-3-0)

* However, I do emphasise to the honourable gentleman that this number of returning <span class="highlight">migrants</span> must be seen against the record number of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who will come to Australia during the course of this year. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700515_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-6-0)

* This means that the achievement during the course of the current financial year will be 8,000 <span class="highlight">migrants</span> more than last year's record total and 9,000 more than the target at which we have been aiming for the present financial year. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700515_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-6-0)

* In relation to the reasons for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> returning to their homelands I point out that the studies which have been taken out indicate that rarely can these reasons be put down to single identifiable causes. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700515_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-6-0)

* In looking at this question one must appreciate that a number of people today recognise that we live in a time in which there is unparalleled mobility between countries, that a number of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> do come to Australia without the intention of permanently remaining here, that some do pass on to other countries and that there are many <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who return to their source countries for reasons which may be personal or related to their employment. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700515_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-6-0)

* Our studies indicate that these reasons account for a substantial number of returning <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700515_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-6-0)

* I ask the Minister for Immigration a question arising from the clause in the migration agreement with Yugoslavia which provides that Yugoslav <span class="highlight">migrants</span> will not be called up for military service in Australia if they are 20 years and 1 month or more at the time when they arrive in Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700515_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-19-0)

* There will be greater provision of part time accelerated courses to meet the needs of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who for economic reasons cannot engage in full time instruction. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700519_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-28-0)

* Advanced teaching techniques will be used to meet the needs of individual groups of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700519_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-28-0)

* The full time intensive course of instruction which was first introduced early in 1969 is designed specifically to meet the needs of professional and other qualified <span class="highlight">migrants</span> for whom an adequate knowledge of English is a pre-requisite to their being suitably employed. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700519_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-28-0)

* As a general rule only <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who have reached a certain educational level are able to benefit effectively from this particular type of instruction. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700519_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-28-0)

* Clause 5 relates to the proposed new arrangements for the child migrant education programme as well as to existing arrangements for adult <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and for fulltime intensive courses of instruction. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700519_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-28-0)

* Full-scale production of material designed specifically for child <span class="highlight">migrants</span> will possibly take two to three years. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700519_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-28-0)

* lt may be useful if I were to explain that schools which will qualify for financial assistance under the special programme for child <span class="highlight">migrants</span> will be those where a special teacher is employed. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700519_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-28-0)

* I have no doubt that in the future a great many settlers will come here from the United States, that as more come they will generate a chain reaction, and in future the United States is likely to become one of our major sources of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700520_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-3-0)

* I believe we need <span class="highlight">migrants</span> at the rate we are getting them, and at the rate we can get them, but it may well be that in accepting the need for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> we are overlooking some real economic facts. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700520_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-21-0)

* <span class="highlight">Migrants</span> corning from foot and mouth disease countries are carefully screened and if they are rural' people (i.e. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700520_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-26-6)

* In some cases these 'rural' <span class="highlight">migrants</span> are allowed to travel by air (e.g. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19700520_reps_27_hor67/#subdebate-26-6)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19701022_reps_27_hor70/#subdebate-0-5)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19701022_reps_27_hor70/#subdebate-3-0)

* Do they suggest that we will receive fewer <span class="highlight">migrants</span> than planned? [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19701022_reps_27_hor70/#subdebate-12-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19701027_reps_27_hor70/#subdebate-9-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1970/19701028_reps_27_hor70/#subdebate-0-5)

* It is estimated that in the 5 years to the end of June 1970 more than 10,600 British assisted <span class="highlight">migrants</span> indicated upon arrival in Australia their intention to proceed to Whyalla. * Without a knowledge of the language <span class="highlight">migrants</span> are not only at a distinct disadvantage in respect of employment but also their general participation in community activities and our way of life is denied to them if they are unable to speak and understand our language. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

* It is not so much a criticism of what has been or is being done for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in this regard but rather that a more comprehensive scheme has been delayed so long, particularly in view of the constant urging by conventions and immigration authorities. * Firstly, having in mind the Government's sustained drive for <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, has this aspect of migration been neglected, or at least, has the Department not been insistent enough in the priority that should be given to migrant education? * Since that time, great changes have taken place in the immigration programme, such as increased numbers, differing types of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and methods of transport. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

* A national campaign seeking the co-operation of voluntary organisations, industries, clubs, progress associations, churches and other sections of the community would be a forward step in the education of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

* This is quite different from the days when practically all <span class="highlight">migrants</span> travelled by ship and an education officer gave them instruction in the English language. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

* As it stands, it means that the Government reluctantly has accepted the fact that it has a responsibility to the children, the States and the teachers to provide some finance for the thousands of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who have been brought to Australia, but it is confining it to the very minimum and leaving the responsibility for finding additional capital to the States. * Only a small percentage will be spent on the education of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, yet this is generally accepted as the most important factor in their assimilation. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

* Many of these <span class="highlight">migrants</span> may never attend an advanced course, perhaps because of lack of educational facilities. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

* Every form of available advertising should be used to impress upon these <span class="highlight">migrants</span> prior to acceptance, embarkation on shipboard or on plane and on arrival how vital it is to learn English in order to enjoy a happy and successful life in Australia. * Whilst not criticising the objectives and the principles prompting the legislation on the education of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, I believe that there are still gaps through which countless thousands of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> will escape the opportunity to learn English and participate in our community, economic and social life. * The first of those conferences dealt substantially with the problems of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> as seen by various workers in the field of immigrant education and interest in the community. * We are told that <span class="highlight">migrants</span> have added $70,000m to our gross national product over 20 years. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

* There are many manifestations that <span class="highlight">migrants</span> are socially disadvantaged in Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710216_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-44-0)

* Firstly, there are the young <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, just out of school, not well educated and thrust immediately on their arrival here into the grinding and mindshackling mills of unskilled employment; and, secondly, there are the older <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, also not well educated but long out of school and confined to the home and thereby effectively isolated from the community in which they will live out their lives and isolated from the community which is supposed to give meaning to their lives. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* But despite this, the Department is insisting that instruction, not only for adolescents and older <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, including those who will hardly be involved in the. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* It is clear that <span class="highlight">migrants</span> cannot be fitted into, for whatever purposes, an homogeneous group. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Rather do <span class="highlight">migrants</span> comprise a number of sub-groups extensively diverse in terms of age, innate ability, achievement and desire for learning the English language. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* It is difficult to escape the conclusion that the Government has no real interest in spreading the use of English among <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who need English instruction hut that the Government is merely interested in turning out human capital, that is, people who will serve the economic machine. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Any programme for the instruction of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in the English language should begin by instructing the foreign speaking migrant in his own language. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* If an expanded programme for English instruction for larger numbers of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> is to be put into operation, a large increase in expenditure will be necessary, An appropriation of $990,000 was made for the education of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in the 1969-70 financial year. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Professor Connell strongly recommended the introduction of day classes for mothers, the expansion of pre-embarkation and on-ship courses and semi-intensive part time courses for all <span class="highlight">migrants</span> wishing to help themselves integrate into their new country. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* This was to be the total grant spread over 3 years and took no account of the educational assistance required by adult <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* So let us ensure thai our <span class="highlight">migrants</span> have a proper understanding of their own language, or their own culture, and of our tongue, by the situation method if you like, but let us instruct them in all three concurrently. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Whether we do this intentionally because we prefer assimilation to integration, or whether the determining factor is blind economic necessity, I have not yet determined, but the essential need of any integration programme is to keep together people who have an affinity of race or nationality, in order that they might strengthen each other during the period of integration, during that period of their lives in which they suffer greatly the inevitable tensions produced by cultural conflict and the material poverty which Professor Henderson tells us so many southern European <span class="highlight">migrants</span> suffer. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* I know of no school in my electorate, which has a high density of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, where additional classroom facilities exist for the provision of a special English class for <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Rightly or wrongly the State governments feel that a far greater expenditure should have been forthcoming from the Commonwealth Government over an extended period on education, housing and other social activites connected with the establishment of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> here. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* <span class="highlight">Migrants</span> mainly find unskilled jobs and if they are prepared to work under conditions which most trade unions would not accept they can earn high incomes. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* My understanding is that the authorities in Yugoslavia also are rather upset about our failure to recognise the trade qualifications of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Yet, the skills of Yugoslavs sent to Australia are not recognised and <span class="highlight">migrants</span> cannot practise their trades here. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* In some areas, notably in the inner city suburbs and in some specific areas of the larger provincial cities, there are very heavy concentrations of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* In areas where there are large concentrations of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> - there are areas where  70  per cent,  80  per cent and up to  90  per cent of the population are <span class="highlight">migrants</span> - the ability to mix or the value of mixing with children who talk English does not exist, and therefore the migrant children are severely handicapped when they begin school. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* <span class="highlight">Migrants</span> arriving in Australia will not get a vote for  5  years after their arrival unless they are English <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, who usually can speak English. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* <span class="highlight">Migrants</span> other than British <span class="highlight">migrants</span> will not have a vote in Australia for 5 years after their arrival. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* The type of social struct rues and prejudices which exist in Australia should be part of the programme in which <span class="highlight">migrants</span> are given instruction. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* I find, as I think most honourable members would, that <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, especially newly arrived <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, have very exaggerated ideas of what they can expect from our social welfare structure. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* These are matters on which I think <span class="highlight">migrants</span> should receive some pre-education or preinstruction. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* I am of the opinion that most <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who want to leave Australia decide before they even arrive here or in their first few weeks in Australia that they are not going to stay. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Tt is in these areas that I think there is great scope for improvement in our public relations with <span class="highlight">migrants</span> coming to Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* The Minister may correct me if I am wrong, birt my understanding is that persons who have left Australia and returned to their own country cannot be used on ships as instructors for <span class="highlight">migrants</span> unless they have been out of Australia for at least 2 years. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* I think that the Department wherever possible should avail itself of qualified people who have returned to their homeland and who are coming back to Australia and should use their knowledge of the country for the instruction of other <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* English <span class="highlight">migrants</span> especially who are returning to Australia are better able to explain the benefits that <span class="highlight">migrants</span> wilt receive in Australia or what goes on in Australia as compared with the position in their own countries. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* These are only minor things but I think they are important to <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* My experience, as 1 said before, is that most disillusioned <span class="highlight">migrants</span> are disillusioned before they get here. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* I represent one of the most heavily concentrated areas of new Australians or <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, call them what we will. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* The Australian community has adopted an attitude of great maturity and has received the <span class="highlight">migrants</span> to its bosom in a very hospitable way, and not often enough does the community get this tribute paid to it. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* From the day the first ship arrived with perhaps 1,200 or 1,500 <span class="highlight">migrants</span> on it, of which perhaps 300 or 400 were of school age, the problem started to expand, and it has been aggrevated by every shipload and every aeroplane load that has arrived since. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* It is the responsibility of nobody else, lt is not good enough for the Minister to pour literally tens of thousands of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> into Victoria, let them try to survive under the tender mercies of the Bolte Government and then say that it is a State matter to supply education and hospitals and to build the roads. * Brunswick and Coburg, 2 centres in my electorate, have one of the greatest concentrations of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Several questions have been raised in this debate about the position of the Australian people regarding the kind of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> that come here. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* There we have the heaviest concentration of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in any inland areas but we also have the highest percentage of citizenship of any major migrant intake area in the nation. * The fundamental problem is that we are putting <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and Australians into situations fraught with dangers for the future of our people. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* The problems of the children of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and the education of <span class="highlight">migrants</span> are bound up with the demographic distribution of population in our community It is quite incredible that the demographic centre of Australia has not changed since the census of 1911. * This is related to the problems of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, because in a situation of over-centralisation and overcrowding the problems are multiplied. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* 1 suggest that when we have an investigation of what we should be doing with the <span class="highlight">migrants</span> coming into our country we should also direct attention to the locations where they are settling. * The problem is related to the overall disposition of our population and to the declining quality of life of Australians and <span class="highlight">migrants</span> alike. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Before I get to the specific questions 1 wish to ask of the Minister on this measure I shall refer in passing to the matters that were directed to me personally by the honourable member for Boothby  (Mr Mclean who described my comments in relation to some <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in the community as quite asinine. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* I ask the Minister whether he has directed his attention to the absorption centres in Israel which has taken in more <span class="highlight">migrants</span> per capita than any other nation in the world, lt has taken people - starting at the top - from rural, professional and urban walks of life. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* These surveys related not only to adult <span class="highlight">migrants</span> but also to migrant children in the schools. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* In late 1967 and early 1968 the Department initiated the planning of a major survey of the educational needs of both adult and child <span class="highlight">migrants</span>, and this led to the report on the situation of migrant children in schools in New South Wales which has provided such an important basis for the new initiatives for child migrant education. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* Complementary studies were undertaken at the same time by my Department which again studied the abandonment rate from continuation classes and the special needs of migrant women and adolescent <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. * These surveys, together with experience gathered over the years, have led to the current policy of developing accelerated forms of instruction to supplement the long term continuation programme and the need for specialisation through courses of instruction orientated towards the particular needs of individual groups of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

[[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* The honourable member for Batman  (Mr Garrick)  referred particularly to the needs of adolescent <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and the older <span class="highlight">migrants</span> confined to their homes - both groups lacking formal education - and he indicated that he believed that the situational method of teaching English was ill-suited to the needs of these particular groups. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* He said that <span class="highlight">migrants</span> should be instructed in their own language, in their own cultures and be taught in classes of their own nationality. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* I can assure the honourable member that the teaching techniques used by my Department are by no means confined to the situational method, though the basic advantages of this method, which is recognised as of international standing, are such that it does allow <span class="highlight">migrants</span> of any number of different nationalities to be taught in one class by one teacher who does not necessarily need to know their languages. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-28-0)

* If so, what action has been taken by his Department to prevent <span class="highlight">migrants</span> or visitors from these countries bringing the disease into Australia. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710217_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-43-23)

* Australia's quarantine measures are based on the knowledge that foot and mouth disease is continually present in these countries and full precautions are always taken to guard against <span class="highlight">migrants</span> and visitors from these countries bringing foot and mouth disease into Australia. * They were mostly <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710218_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-29-0)

* These people were mostly <span class="highlight">migrants</span> who had just come to this country. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710218_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-29-0)

* The Commonwealth Government is understandably reluctant to restrict the flow of <span class="highlight">migrants</span>. [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19710218_reps_27_hor71/#subdebate-29-0)

* I would add the comment, by way of illustration, that if the Government brings in 175,000 <span class="highlight">migrants</span> again it inevitably puts upon the States the duty of making available classroom space and teachers for the children, more hospital accommodation, more housing, more transport. * I suggest to the honourable member that I regard <span class="highlight">migrants</span> in my electorate as being human beings- [[More&hellip;]](https://historichansard.net/hofreps/1971/19711028_reps_27_hor74/#debate-52)
